Moving on from Hydrogen

Hydrogen, the simple Hamiltonian

Energy

The energy of a Hydrogenic atom doesn't depend on l.

En=Z2me4(4πϵ0)22ℏ2n2=RZ2n2E_n= \frac{Z^2me^4}{(4\pi\epsilon_0)^22\hbar^2n^2} = R\frac{Z^2}{n^2} En​=(4πϵ0​)22ℏ2n2Z2me4​=Rn2Z2​

Angular Momentum

Angular wavefunctions are eigenfunctions of lll and mlm_lml​.

Radial Wavefunctions

  • l=0l=0l=0 do not vanish at r=0r=0r=0
  • l = / 0l\ \rlap{=}\ /\ 0l = / 0 vanishes at r=0r=0r=0
  • Max probability is further out as lll increases
  • Size and position of peak probability scales with nnn
  • There are n−ln-ln−l nodes
  • So l=n−1l=n-1l=n−1 has only one node at r=0r=0r=0

A Complicated Hamiltonian

The hydrogenic hamiltonian is now pretty well known to us...

H^=ℏ2m∇2+Ze24πϵ0r\hat{H} = \frac{\hbar}{2m}\nabla^2 + \frac{Ze^2}{4\pi\epsilon_0r} H^=2mℏ​∇2+4πϵ0​rZe2​

For a many electron atom however the Hamiltonian gets much more complicated, the best way is to figure out some big hydrogenic term (a central field) and apply small perturbations to it which is what we'll do in the next section.

The Central Field Approximation

The Hamiltonian built of ever smaller approximations for an atom looks like this...

H^=H0^+H1^+H2^+H3^+...where H0^=Electrons in central fieldH1^=Residual electrostatic fieldH2^=Spin orbit interactionH3^=Hyperfine Structure... =Further approximations\begin{aligned} \hat{H} &= \hat{H_0} + \hat{H_1} + \hat{H_2} + \hat{H_3} + ...\\ \text{where } \hat{H_0} &= \text{Electrons in central field}\\ \hat{H_1} &= \text{Residual electrostatic field}\\ \hat{H_2} &= \text{Spin orbit interaction}\\ \hat{H_3} &= \text{Hyperfine Structure}\\ ...\ &= \text{Further approximations}\\ \end{aligned} H^where H0​^​H1​^​H2​^​H3​^​... ​=H0​^​+H1​^​+H2​^​+H3​^​+...=Electrons in central field=Residual electrostatic field=Spin orbit interaction=Hyperfine Structure=Further approximations​

We like to deal with cases where H1^>H2^\hat{H_1} > \hat{H_2}H1​^​>H2​^​ but this isn't always the case. We say that:

  • H0^\hat{H_0}H0​^​ defines energy levels in the quantum numbers nnn and lll and is called gross structure
  • H1^\hat{H_1}H1​^​ splits degeneracy in levels into terms
  • H2^\hat{H_2}H2​^​ will split terms into fine structure
  • Nuclear effects lead to hyperfine structure

We can now get started looking into these one by one.

Gross Structure

The hamiltonian of a multi electron atom (considering only the electrostatic interaction between electrons and the nucleus) looks a bit like this...

H^=∑i=1N{−ℏ22m∇i2−Ze24πϵ0ri}⏞Contribution of each electron in the central field+∑i>je24πϵ0rij⎵Mutual electrostatic interaction between electrons\begin{aligned} \hat{H} = \overbrace{\sum^N_{i=1}\bigg\{-\frac{\hbar^2}{2m}\nabla^2_i - \frac{Ze^2}{4\pi\epsilon_0r_i}\bigg\}}^\text{Contribution of each electron in the central field} + \underbrace{\sum_{i>j}\frac{e^2}{4\pi\epsilon_0r_{ij}}}_\text{Mutual electrostatic interaction between electrons} \end{aligned} H^=i=1∑N​{−2mℏ2​∇i2​−4πϵ0​ri​Ze2​}​Contribution of each electron in the central field​+Mutual electrostatic interaction between electronsi>j∑​4πϵ0​rij​e2​​​​

This can't be split into hamiltonians for each electron due to the second mutual interaction term. This term is also too large to be treated as a perturbation! Clearly we are in a bit of a situation. Luckily there's a solution.

The Central Field

To make our lives easier we want solutions of a similar form as the Hydrogenic ones which we can then apply a perturbation to. This means we want a central 1r\frac{1}{r}r1​ potential which allows us to separate the angular and radial components like we did for the Hydrogenic case. Since most of the time a major part of electron interaction acts radially we can combine that part with the central nuclear potential to get the Central Field. We now have the Hamiltonian.

H^=H0^+H1^where H0^=∑i{−ℏ22m∇i2+U(ri)}and H1^=∑i>je24πϵ0rij−∑i{Ze24πϵ0ri+U(ri)}\begin{aligned} \hat{H} &= \hat{H_0} + \hat{H_1}\\ \text{where } \hat{H_0} &= \sum_i\bigg\{-\frac{\hbar^2}{2m}\nabla^2_i + U(r_i)\bigg\}\\ \text{and } \hat{H_1} &= \sum_{i>j}\frac{e^2}{4\pi\epsilon_0r_{ij}} - \sum_i\bigg\{\frac{Ze^2}{4\pi\epsilon_0r_i} + U(r_i)\bigg\} \end{aligned} H^where H0​^​and H1​^​​=H0​^​+H1​^​=i∑​{−2mℏ2​∇i2​+U(ri​)}=i>j∑​4πϵ0​rij​e2​−i∑​{4πϵ0​ri​Ze2​+U(ri​)}​

Here H1^\hat{H_1}H1​^​ is the residual electrostatic interaction (the part that isn't radial) this means we can assume that H1^<<H0^\hat{H_1}<<\hat{H_0}H1​^​<<H0​^​ which is great because we can now apply some good old fashioned perturbation theory. By comparing to the Hamiltonian of a Hydrogenic atom we can see the solutions will be of the form...

ψ(n,l,ml,ms)=Rn,l′(r)Ylm(θ,ϕ)χ(ms)\psi(n,l,m_l,m_s) = R'_{n,l}(r)Y^m_l(\theta, \phi)\chi(m_s) ψ(n,l,ml​,ms​)=Rn,l′​(r)Ylm​(θ,ϕ)χ(ms​)

In this approximation we still have angular and spin functions (Ylm(θ,ϕ)Y^m_l(\theta, \phi)Ylm​(θ,ϕ) and χ(ms)\chi(m_s)χ(ms​)) as the same but Rn,l′(r)R'_{n,l}(r)Rn,l′​(r), the radial function, will be a little different.

Form of the Central Field

It's clear that close to the atom the central field looks like the field of the nucleus, far away the potentials will sum and the Z−1Z-1Z−1 other electrons will cancel out the ZZZ charge of the nucleus leaving us with a 1r\frac{1}{r}r1​ potential. The result is something like this...

This gives a ZeffZ_\text{eff}Zeff​ value which decreases with r.

Electronic Configurations

Electronic configurations can be guessed at using two key principles

  1. The Pauli Exclusion Principle, no more than one electron can be in any state.
  2. Principle of least energy, electrons fill lowest states first.

So low energy states are filled one at a time, it's worth noting that under the central field levels are no longer degenerate in lll so that's why I do that more detail on that in a bit.

Spectroscopic Notation

This is a useful bit of notation for representing energy levels,

1s22s22p61s^22s^22p^61s22s22p6 represents the energy levels 1s21s^21s2 means two electrons are in the level with n=1n=1n=1 and l=0l=0l=0, 2p62p^62p6 represents 6 electrons in the energy level n=2n=2n=2, l=1l=1l=1.

Full spectroscopic notation includes totals at the end.

2S+1LJ^{2S+1}L_J2S+1LJ​ 2S+12S+12S+1 is the multiplicity due to spin, L is orbital angular momentum and J total angular momentum.

The letters used to represent numbers is an annoying thing from old fashioned spectroscopy that everyone secretly loves. Just remember, s=0,p=1,d=2,f=3,g=4s=0, p=1, d=2, f=3, g=4s=0,p=1,d=2,f=3,g=4 and it continues alphabetically from there.

Constructing a Periodic table

I wonder if we can explain some of the periodic table now? Shockingly we can.

As we can see the lower states fill up first (again the lack of degeneracy in lll will be explained in a bit) we have a degeneracy of 2 in sss and 6 in ppp the interesting part is that at the 4th energy level the lll effect becomes large enough to span energy levels and 3d3d3d comes after 4s4s4s it's actually even more messy than the picture would like us to believe as at Chromium we get,

Va: 3s23p6  3d34s23s^23p^6\ \ 3d^34s^23s23p6  3d34s2

Cr: 3s23p6  3d54s13s^23p^6\ \ 3d^54s^13s23p6  3d54s1

Mn: 3s23p6  3d54s23s^23p^6\ \ 3d^54s^23s23p6  3d54s2

Here a 3d3d3d electron takes precedence over a 4s4s4s for a bit! It's off syllabus so luckily we don't have to worry about it hut still it makes me sick.

Rare Gases

A key feature of the periodic table is the rare gases. These are chemically inert with high ionisation potentials. This isn't because they have "closed" shells (states for each n are all filled) but because they have filled s and p subshells. This leads to a spherically symmetric charge distribution electrons are now indistinguishable and take on a common wavefunction which results in higher binding energies for all leading to the classic Rare gases we know and love.

Alkalis

Alkalis are the element next to rare gases and have one electron outside the filled (sp) these are generally very well screened from the attracting nuclear force. This means they have very low ionisation energies and are chemically reactive.

First Ionisation

What does this look like then?

We get a periodic situation with a rising trend of first ionisation energies from alkalis to rare gases with some weirdness inbetween. It's worth noting that after first ionisation, the second ionisation energies se atoms shift down one. Alkaline +1 ions become the most stable.

Energy of Alkalis, the Quantum Defect

As we established in the Alkalis section above, alkalis single outer 'valence' electron moving in a central field of the closed shells. The further out from the nucleus the valence electron is the more it is shielded from it's attraction by the bound electrons of the closed shell. This is why the shape of the wavefunction in R (and therefore lll) affects the energy level. Looking at the Radial Wavefunctions section we can see that lower levels of lll penetrate the core more so we would expect these to have higher energy. It's also important that core penetration depends very little on nnn this means that deviation from the Hydrogenic case is almost constant as we move through n states in the valence electron. Alkaline energy levels can be expressed almost like hydrogen then...

En=R(n∗)2E_n = \frac{R}{(n^*)^2} En​=(n∗)2R​

where n* is the effective quantum number

n∗=n−δ(l)n^* = n - \delta(l) n∗=n−δ(l)

Where δ(l)\delta(l)δ(l) is called the quantum defect and is found empirically. δ(l)\delta(l)δ(l) can be shown to be independent of nnn and decreases as lll increases.

For heavier Alkalis δ(l)\delta(l)δ(l) increases but ionisation energies stay about the same as valence electrons start at higher values of nnn

One convenient part of the quantum defect is that it helps us identify the source of emission lines in a spectrum. To do this we use the fact that lines of the same quantum defect will correspond to levels of the same angular momentum thus be in the same series.

Residual Electrostatic Interaction

A Degenerate Perturbation

For atoms with two electrons we need to start considering the Residual electrostatic interaction. This is represented by the Hamiltonian H1^\hat{H_1}H1​^​

This means that (considering the (closed shell) 3s4s3s4s3s4s state of magnesium,

ΔE1=<ψ1(3s)ψ2(4s)∣H1^∣ψ1(3s)ψ2(4s)>\Delta E_1 = \big<\psi_1(3s)\psi_2(4s)|\hat{H_1}|\psi_1(3s)\psi_2(4s)\big> ΔE1​=⟨ψ1​(3s)ψ2​(4s)∣H1​^​∣ψ1​(3s)ψ2​(4s)⟩

Physically we would expect swapping ψ1\psi_1ψ1​ and ψ2\psi_2ψ2​ to have no effect. This means that states ∣ψ1(3s)ψ2(4s)>|\psi_1(3s)\psi_2(4s)\big>∣ψ1​(3s)ψ2​(4s)⟩ and ∣ψ2(3s)ψ1(4s)>|\psi_2(3s)\psi_1(4s)\big>∣ψ2​(3s)ψ1​(4s)⟩ are degenerate and now we have to use degenerate perturbation theory. This means we need to make linear combinations of our zero order states to diagonalise H1^\hat{H_1}H1​^​ which is actually not too bad. From our derivation of The Central Field we remember that,

H1^=∑i>je24πϵ0rij−∑i{Ze24πϵ0ri+U(ri)}\hat{H_1} = \sum_{i>j}\frac{e^2}{4\pi\epsilon_0r_{ij}} - \sum_i\bigg\{\frac{Ze^2}{4\pi\epsilon_0r_i} + U(r_i)\bigg\} H1​^​=i>j∑​4πϵ0​rij​e2​−i∑​{4πϵ0​ri​Ze2​+U(ri​)}

The second sum (over i) completely disappears as the 1ri\frac{1}{r_i}ri​1​ term is a single electron operator so doesn't matter and the zero order states are eigenfunctions of the second U(ri)U(r_i)U(ri​) term. This leaves us to diagonalise the first sum only. We can start by considering the two orthogonal functions

ϕ1=aψ1(3s)ψ2(4s)+bψ1(4s)ψ2(3s)ϕ2=b∗ψ1(3s)ψ2(4s)−a∗ψ1(4s)ψ2(3s)\begin{aligned} \phi_1 &= a\psi_1(3s)\psi_2(4s) + b\psi_1(4s)\psi_2(3s)\\ \phi_2 &= b^*\psi_1(3s)\psi_2(4s) - a^*\psi_1(4s)\psi_2(3s) \end{aligned} ϕ1​ϕ2​​=aψ1​(3s)ψ2​(4s)+bψ1​(4s)ψ2​(3s)=b∗ψ1​(3s)ψ2​(4s)−a∗ψ1​(4s)ψ2​(3s)​

Now we just need to find values of aaa and bbb where <ϕ1∣V∣ϕ2>=0\big<\phi_1|V|\phi_2\big>=0⟨ϕ1​∣V∣ϕ2​⟩=0 with V being that first term in H the two electron electrostatic repulsion. V doesn't distinguish ϕ1\phi_1ϕ1​ and ϕ2\phi_2ϕ2​ so ∣a∣=∣b∣|a|=|b|∣a∣=∣b∣ which means ∣a∣=∣b∣=12|a|=|b|=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}∣a∣=∣b∣=2​1​ if we want normalisation.

If we write a couple of definitions,

J=<ϕ1(3s)ϕ2(4s)∣V∣ϕ1(3s)ϕ2(4s)>The direct integralK=<ϕ1(3s)ϕ2(4s)∣V∣ϕ1(4s)ϕ2(3s)> The exchange integral\begin{aligned} J &= \big<\phi_1(3s)\phi_2(4s)|V|\phi_1(3s)\phi_2(4s)\big>&\text{The direct integral}\\ K &= \big<\phi_1(3s)\phi_2(4s)|V|\phi_1(4s)\phi_2(3s)\big>&\text{ The exchange integral}\\ \end{aligned} JK​=⟨ϕ1​(3s)ϕ2​(4s)∣V∣ϕ1​(3s)ϕ2​(4s)⟩=⟨ϕ1​(3s)ϕ2​(4s)∣V∣ϕ1​(4s)ϕ2​(3s)⟩​The direct integral The exchange integral​

Then we can calculate matrix elements

<ϕ1∣V∣ϕ1>=ΔE1=J+K singlet<ϕ2∣V∣ϕ2>=ΔE2=J−K triplet\begin{aligned} \big<\phi_1|V|\phi_1\big> &= \Delta E_1 = J + K &\text{ singlet}\\ \big<\phi_2|V|\phi_2\big> &= \Delta E_2 = J - K &\text{ triplet} \end{aligned} ⟨ϕ1​∣V∣ϕ1​⟩⟨ϕ2​∣V∣ϕ2​⟩​=ΔE1​=J+K=ΔE2​=J−K​ singlet triplet​

The off diagonals are zero as that was kind of the point of all this. A big question is "How do I know which one is the triplet?" and it's a good question.

Symmetry, Antisymmetry and Spin

The degeneracy comes from the resolution of symmetry with spin! ϕ1\phi_1ϕ1​ is a symmetric state and ϕ2\phi_2ϕ2​ is antisymmetric but electrons are all antisymmetric so something must be done! They have to paired with the right spin states...

↑1↑2, ↓1↓2,12(↑1↓2+↓1↑2): symmetric12(↑1↓2−↓1↑2): antisymmetric\begin{aligned} \uparrow_1\uparrow_2,\ \downarrow_1\downarrow_2, &\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(\uparrow_1\downarrow_2 + \downarrow_1\uparrow_2):\ \text{symmetric}\\ &\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(\uparrow_1\downarrow_2 - \downarrow_1\uparrow_2):\ \text{antisymmetric} \end{aligned} ↑1​↑2​, ↓1​↓2​,​2​1​(↑1​↓2​+↓1​↑2​): symmetric2​1​(↑1​↓2​−↓1​↑2​): antisymmetric​

The antisymmetric spin states pair with the symmetric wavefunctions and vice versa, this means the antisymmetric state ϕ2\phi_2ϕ2​ has spin degeneracy of 3 making it a triplet and the symmetric state ϕ1\phi_1ϕ1​ is a singlet as it combines with just the ones antisymmetric spin state.

Spin Orbit Interaction (Fine Structure)

The spin orbit interaction is the hamiltonian term arising from considering magnetic fields, specifically those produced by electron spin and orbit.

The Physics

If you want to skip to the end of this bit it's just ΔE=−μ‾⋅B‾\Delta E = -\underline{\mu} \cdot \underline{B}ΔE=−μ​⋅B​

The angular momentum of a spinning electron is Iω‾=λ‾ℏI\underline{\omega}=\underline{\lambda}\hbarIω​=λ​ℏ the energy then is E=12Iω2E=\frac{1}{2}I\omega^2E=21​Iω2. The magnetic moment of the rotating electron is μ‾=−γλ‾ℏ\underline{\mu}=-\gamma\underline{\lambda}\hbarμ​=−γλ​ℏ where the minus sign is for negative charge and γ\gammaγ is the gyromagnetic ratio. If a constant B field is applied on the z axis then the moment μ\muμ will precess about that axis with some frequency ω′\omega^\primeω′ so angular motion changes like so:

ω→ω+ω′cosθOr (if λ‾ℏ is in the opposite direction)ω→ω−ω′cosθ\omega \rightarrow \omega + \omega^\prime cos\theta\\ \text{Or (if $\underline{\lambda}\hbar$ is in the opposite direction)}\\ \omega \rightarrow \omega - \omega^\prime cos\theta ω→ω+ω′cosθOr (if λ​ℏ is in the opposite direction)ω→ω−ω′cosθ

So the new energy is:

E′=12I(ω±ω′cosθ)2=12Iω2+12I(ω′cosθ)2±Iωω′cosθ\begin{aligned} E^\prime &= \frac{1}{2}I(\omega \pm \omega^\prime cos\theta)^2\\ &=\frac{1}{2}I\omega^2 + \frac{1}{2}I(\omega^\prime cos\theta)^2 \pm I\omega\omega^\prime cos\theta \end{aligned} E′​=21​I(ω±ω′cosθ)2=21​Iω2+21​I(ω′cosθ)2±Iωω′cosθ​

Assuming speed at which the axis precesses to be slow compared to original angular velocity we can say that ω′⋘ω\omega^\prime \llless \omegaω′⋘ω which means (ω′cosθ)2⋘ω2(\omega^\prime cos\theta)^2 \llless \omega^2(ω′cosθ)2⋘ω2 this means the energy change ΔE=E′−E\Delta E = E^\prime - EΔE=E′−E is:

ΔE=Iωω′cosθ=λℏω′cosθ\begin{aligned} \Delta E &= I\omega\omega^\prime cos\theta\\ &= \lambda\hbar\omega^\prime cos\theta \end{aligned} ΔE​=Iωω′cosθ=λℏω′cosθ​

We know from Lamor's Theorem that ω′=−γB\omega^\prime = -\gamma Bω′=−γB so...

ΔE=−γλℏBcosθ=−μ‾⋅B‾\begin{aligned} \Delta E &= -\gamma\lambda\hbar Bcos\theta\\ &=-\underline{\mu} \cdot\underline{B} \end{aligned} ΔE​=−γλℏBcosθ=−μ​⋅B​​

Finding the Spin Orbit Correction

Now we can say that

H^2=−μ^‾⋅B‾ΔE=−<μ^‾⋅B‾>\begin{aligned} \hat{H}_2 &= -\underline{\hat{\mu}} \cdot\underline{B}\\ \Delta E &= -\big<\underline{\hat{\mu}} \cdot\underline{B}\big> \end{aligned} H^2​ΔE​=−μ^​​⋅B​=−⟨μ^​​⋅B​⟩​

So we need...

  • To find the B Field
  • Have an operator for −μ^‾⋅B‾-\underline{\hat{\mu}} \cdot\underline{B}−μ^​​⋅B​ depending on rrr, s‾\underline{s}s​, and l‾\underline{l}l​
  • Perform some perturbation theory

The B Field due to Orbital Motion

The field the electrons experience is the one produced by the electronic orbital motion. This is given by...

B‾=−v‾×E‾c2\underline{B} = -\frac{\underline{v}\times \underline{E}}{c^2} B​=−c2v​×E​​

as p‾=mv‾\underline{p} = m\underline{v}p​=mv​

B‾=−1mc2p‾×E‾\underline{B} = -\frac{1}{mc^2}\underline{p}\times\underline{E} B​=−mc21​p​×E​

Remembering E is purely radial in the central field we can rewrite it B‾\underline{B}B​:

B‾=−1mc2p‾×r‾∣E‾∣∣r‾∣\underline{B} = -\frac{1}{mc^2}\underline{p}\times\underline{r}\frac{|\underline{E}|}{|\underline{r}|} B​=−mc21​p​×r​∣r​∣∣E​∣​

Luckily r‾×p‾=l‾\underline{r}\times\underline{p} = \underline{l}r​×p​=l​ so:

B‾=1mc2∣E‾∣∣r‾∣l^‾\underline{B} = \frac{1}{mc^2}\frac{|\underline{E}|}{|\underline{r}|}\underline{\hat{l}} B​=mc21​∣r​∣∣E​∣​l^​

∣E‾∣=∂ϕ∂r|\underline{E}| = \frac{\partial\phi}{\partial r}∣E​∣=∂r∂ϕ​ and eϕ(r)=U(r)e\phi(r) = U(r)eϕ(r)=U(r) so ∣E‾∣=−1r∂U(r)∂r|\underline{E}| = -\frac{1}{r}\frac{\partial U(r)}{\partial r}∣E​∣=−r1​∂r∂U(r)​. Putting it all together we have:

B‾=1emc21r∂U(r)∂rl^‾\underline{B} = \frac{1}{emc^2}\frac{1}{r}\frac{\partial U(r)}{\partial r}\underline{\hat{l}} B​=emc21​r1​∂r∂U(r)​l^​

U(r) is the central potential.

Finding Our Operator

The operator we need to find is −μs‾⋅B‾-\underline{\mu_s} \cdot \underline{B}−μs​​⋅B​. The intrinsic magnetic moment of an electron due to spin is:

μs‾=−gsμBℏs^‾\underline{\mu_s} = -g_s\frac{\mu_B}{\hbar}\underline{\hat{s}} μs​​=−gs​ℏμB​​s^​

So

−μs‾⋅B‾=−gsμBℏ1emc21r∂U(r)∂rs^‾⋅l^‾-\underline{\mu_s} \cdot \underline{B} = -g_s\frac{\mu_B}{\hbar}\frac{1}{emc^2}\frac{1}{r}\frac{\partial U(r)}{\partial r}\underline{\hat{s}}\cdot\underline{\hat{l}} −μs​​⋅B​=−gs​ℏμB​​emc21​r1​∂r∂U(r)​s^​⋅l^​

Sadly most of the time we don't know the form of U(r). It is a great tragedy but we must soldier on. We can at least see that the energy operator is proportional to 1r∂U(r)∂rs^‾⋅l^‾\frac{1}{r}\frac{\partial U(r)}{\partial r}\underline{\hat{s}}\cdot\underline{\hat{l}}r1​∂r∂U(r)​s^​⋅l^​ which is positive and determined by the relative orientation of s^‾\underline{\hat{s}}s^​ and l^‾\underline{\hat{l}}l^​ which is nice. A hydrogen atom has the potential U(r)=−Ze24πϵ0rU(r) = -\frac{Ze^2}{4\pi\epsilon_0r}U(r)=−4πϵ0​rZe2​ this gives:

−μs‾⋅B‾=μB4π2ZgsμB21r3s^‾⋅l^‾ℏ2 -\underline{\mu_s} \cdot \underline{B} = \frac{\mu_B}{4\pi}2Zg_s\mu_B^2\frac{1}{r^3}\frac{\underline{\hat{s}}\cdot\underline{\hat{l}}}{\hbar^2} −μs​​⋅B​=4πμB​​2Zgs​μB2​r31​ℏ2s^​⋅l^​​

Although if you take into account the relativistic correction of Thomas Precession which isn't on syllabus we need to divide by 2 so:

−μs‾⋅B‾=μB4πZgsμB21r3s^‾⋅l^‾ℏ2 -\underline{\mu_s} \cdot \underline{B} = \frac{\mu_B}{4\pi}Zg_s\mu_B^2\frac{1}{r^3}\frac{\underline{\hat{s}}\cdot\underline{\hat{l}}}{\hbar^2} −μs​​⋅B​=4πμB​​Zgs​μB2​r31​ℏ2s^​⋅l^​​

Doing the Work

ΔE=μB4πℏ2ZgsμB2<1r3><s^‾⋅l^‾>\Delta E = \frac{\mu_B}{4\pi\hbar^2}Zg_s\mu_B^2\big<\frac{1}{r^3}\big>\big<\underline{\hat{s}}\cdot\underline{\hat{l}}\big> ΔE=4πℏ2μB​​Zgs​μB2​⟨r31​⟩⟨s^​⋅l^​⟩

The radial part is a standard radial integral using hydrogenic wavefunctions.

<1r3>=∫0∞Rn,l2(r)1r3r2dr=Z3n3a03l(l+1/2)(l+1)\begin{aligned} \big<\frac{1}{r^3}\big> &= \int_0^{\infin}R^2_{n,l}(r)\frac{1}{r^3}r^2dr\\ &=\frac{Z^3}{n^3a_0^3l(l+1/2)(l+1)} \end{aligned} ⟨r31​⟩​=∫0∞​Rn,l2​(r)r31​r2dr=n3a03​l(l+1/2)(l+1)Z3​​

the dot product is a bit harder but we can use the power of the vector model.

j^‾  =s^‾+l^‾  ⟹  j^‾2=s^‾2+l^‾2+s^‾⋅l^‾∴s^‾⋅l^‾=j^‾2−s^‾2+l^‾2\begin{aligned} \underline{\hat{j}}\ \ &= \underline{\hat{s}} + \underline{\hat{l}}\\ \implies\underline{\hat{j}}^2&=\underline{\hat{s}}^2 + \underline{\hat{l}}^2+\underline{\hat{s}}\cdot\underline{\hat{l}}\\ \therefore\underline{\hat{s}}\cdot\underline{\hat{l}}&=\underline{\hat{j}}^2 - \underline{\hat{s}}^2 + \underline{\hat{l}}^2 \end{aligned} j^​​  ⟹j^​​2∴s^​⋅l^​​=s^​+l^​=s^​2+l^​2+s^​⋅l^​=j^​​2−s^​2+l^​2​

This means that we can write our matrix elements in a different basis as ∣n,l,ml,s,ms>|n,l,m_l,s,m_s\big>∣n,l,ml​,s,ms​⟩ is not diagonalised.

<n,l,s,j,mj∣s^‾⋅l^‾∣n′,l′,s′,j′,mj′>=0 unless j=j′ and mj=mj′\big<n,l,s,j,m_j|\underline{\hat{s}}\cdot\underline{\hat{l}}|n',l',s',j',m_j'\big> = 0 \text{ unless } j=j'\text{ and } m_j=m_j' ⟨n,l,s,j,mj​∣s^​⋅l^​∣n′,l′,s′,j′,mj′​⟩=0 unless j=j′ and mj​=mj′​

The diagonal elements are then:

<n,l,s,j,mj∣s^‾⋅l^‾∣n′,l′,s′,j′,mj′>=12{j(j+1)−l(l+1)−s(s+1)}ℏ2\big<n,l,s,j,m_j|\underline{\hat{s}}\cdot\underline{\hat{l}}|n',l',s',j',m_j'\big> = \frac{1}{2}\{j(j+1) - l(l+1) - s(s+1)\}\hbar^2 ⟨n,l,s,j,mj​∣s^​⋅l^​∣n′,l′,s′,j′,mj′​⟩=21​{j(j+1)−l(l+1)−s(s+1)}ℏ2

This is a nice result but what does this mean? We found that we need a new basis when we consider spin orbit. This is because without spin orbit s^‾\underline{\hat{s}}s^​ and l^‾\underline{\hat{l}}l^​ are fixed, making their projections in z good quantum numbers. When we consider spin orbit though s^‾\underline{\hat{s}}s^​ and l^‾\underline{\hat{l}}l^​ precess around their mutual sum j^‾\underline{\hat{j}}j^​​ which means mlm_lml​ ans msm_sms​ are no longer constants of motion. Clearly it is important to choose a basis which suits the perturbation we're doing.

Final Result for Spin Orbit

Using

H2^∝1r∂U(r)∂rs^‾⋅l^‾\hat{H_2} \propto\frac{1}{r}\frac{\partial U(r)}{\partial r}\underline{\hat{s}}\cdot\underline{\hat{l}} H2​^​∝r1​∂r∂U(r)​s^​⋅l^​

We can find perturbed energy:

ΔESO=<H2^>=βn,l12{j(j+1)−l(l+1)−s(s+1)}ℏ2\Delta E_{SO} = \big<\hat{H_2}\big> = \beta_{n,l} \frac{1}{2}\{j(j+1) - l(l+1) - s(s+1)\}\hbar^2 ΔESO​=⟨H2​^​⟩=βn,l​21​{j(j+1)−l(l+1)−s(s+1)}ℏ2

Where for hydrogen molecules:

βnl=μ0Z4gsμb24π1n3a03l(l+1/2)(l+1)\beta_{nl} = \frac{\mu_0Z^4g_s\mu_b^2}{4\pi}\frac{1}{n^3a_0^3l(l+1/2)(l+1)} βnl​=4πμ0​Z4gs​μb2​​n3a03​l(l+1/2)(l+1)1​

For single electron atoms (alkalis) j has twofold degeneracy j=l±1/2j =l\pm 1/2j=l±1/2 so energy levels are split in two.

LS-Coupling

In these notes we assume LS-Coupling because it's super convenient and I like it. In LS coupling J‾=L‾+S‾\underline{J}= \underline{L} +\underline{S}J​=L​+S​ which in vector model terms means that L‾\underline{L}L​ and S‾\underline{S}S​ couple to precess around J‾\underline{J}J​ which makes L,S,J,L,S,J,L,S,J, and MJM_JMJ​ good quantum numbers but MLM_LML​ and MSM_SMS​ obviously not.

Nuclear Effects

So far we assume the nucleus is simple, and pointlike with infinite mass, this is obviously not true! The effect of nucleic movement, distributed charge, and spinning leading to a magnetic field leads to corrections to the energy levels of an atom.

Hyperfine Structure

The magnetic affect mentioned is called hyperfine structure and we'll look at it below.

Electronic magnetic moments are described by the equations provided by Quantum Physics.

μ‾s=−gsμBℏs‾ μ‾l=−glμBℏl‾ μ‾j=μs‾+μ‾l\underline{\mu}_s = -g_s\frac{\mu_B}{\hbar}\underline{s}\\ \ \\ \underline{\mu}_l = -g_l\frac{\mu_B}{\hbar}\underline{l}\\ \ \\ \underline{\mu}_j = \underline{\mu_s} + \underline{\mu}_l μ​s​=−gs​ℏμB​​s​ μ​l​=−gl​ℏμB​​l​ μ​j​=μs​​+μ​l​

gs=2g_s = 2gs​=2 adn gl=1g_l = 1gl​=1 (with s and l in units of ℏ\hbarℏ). The coefficient μB\mu_BμB​ is the bohr magneton, μB=eℏ2m\mu_B = \frac{e\hbar}{2m}μB​=2meℏ​ for the Nuclear moment we have,

μ‾I=gIμNℏI‾gI∼1μN=μB×memp\underline{\mu}_I = g_I\frac{\mu_N}{\hbar}\underline{I}\\ g_I\sim1\\ \mu_N = \mu_B \times \frac{m_e}{m_p}\\ μ​I​=gI​ℏμN​​I​gI​∼1μN​=μB​×mp​me​​

I‾\underline{I}I​ is the vector operator for total nuclear spin. The relationship between μN\mu_NμN​ and μB\mu_BμB​ means that μ‾I⋘μ‾s,μ‾l\underline{\mu}_I \llless \underline{\mu}_s, \underline{\mu}_lμ​I​⋘μ​s​,μ​l​ so the magnetic interaction will be small. This leads to a much slower precession which is great because that means I‾\underline{I}I​ and J‾\underline{J}J​ will remain nice and well defined. We can write the perturbation as:

H^3=−μ^‾I⋅B^‾el\hat{H}_3 = -\underline{\hat{\mu}}_I \cdot \underline{\hat{B}}_{el} H^3​=−μ^​​I​⋅B^​el​

The magnetic field is proportional to the total angular momentum of electrons J‾\underline{J}J​ and we've seen that μ‾I∝I‾\underline{\mu}_I \propto \underline{I}μ​I​∝I​ so we get a constant of proportionality AJA_JAJ​.

H^3=AJI⋅J.\hat{H}_3 = A_J I\cdot J. H^3​=AJ​I⋅J.

Toby derives AJA_JAJ​ but the lecturer seems to think it isn't important.

Let's let F‾=I‾+J‾\underline{F} = \underline{I} + \underline{J}F​=I​+J​ this gives:

I‾⋅J‾=12(F‾2−I‾2−J‾2)   ⟹  ΔE3=AJ2(F(F+1)−I(I+1)−J(J+1))\underline{I}\cdot\underline{J} = \frac{1}{2}(\underline{F}^2 - \underline{I}^2 - \underline{J}^2)\\ \ \\ \implies \Delta E_3 = \frac{A_J}{2}\bigg(F(F+1) - I(I+1) - J(J+1)\bigg) I​⋅J​=21​(F​2−I​2−J​2) ⟹ΔE3​=2AJ​​(F(F+1)−I(I+1)−J(J+1))

This leads to the useful interval rule,

ΔEF=ΔE(F)−ΔE(F−1)∼AJF\Delta E_F = \Delta E(F) - \Delta E(F-1) \sim A_J F ΔEF​=ΔE(F)−ΔE(F−1)∼AJ​F

The number of levels produced by hyperfine splitting depends on the values of F, these follow the rule:

number of levels={2I+1  if  I<J2J+1  if  J<I\text{number of levels}= \bigg\{ \begin{gathered} 2I+1\ \text{ if }\ I<J\\ 2J+1\ \text{ if }\ J<I \end{gathered} number of levels={2I+1  if  I<J2J+1  if  J<I​

Finding I

To find I we need to examine the hyperfine structure. This structure has the selection rules,

ΔF=0,±1 but not 0→0\Delta F = 0, \pm1 \text{ but not } 0\rightarrow0 ΔF=0,±1 but not 0→0

From there there are three methods:

  • Interval Rule The interval between FFF and F−1F-1F−1 is proportional to the higher level, (FFF) we can use this to find III if we know JJJ
  • Number of Spectral Lines using the degeneracy rules above we can find III if we know I<JI<JI<J.
  • Relative Intensities the realtive intensities of spectral components is proportional to the statistical weight of the 2F+12F+12F+1 hyperfine structure levels. So we can find III if we know JJJ

External Magnetic Fields

A final thing to consider the perturbation provided by a magnetic field and how that affects our previous energy levels. It's clear that the hamiltonian for this perturbation would be:

H^mag=μ‾atom⋅B‾ext\hat{H}_{mag} = \underline{\mu}_{atom} \cdot \underline{B}_{ext} H^mag​=μ​atom​⋅B​ext​

Where does this sit on our hierarchy of perturbations? Most laboratory magnets are stronger than the hyperfine perturbation and weaker than the electrostatic (and Central Field), this means we only need to figure out where it sits with regard to the spin orbit (which is annoyingly difficult).

Magnetic Effects in Fine Structure

Weak Field, No Spin, Normal Zeeman Effect

Without spin (and spin orbit) we have μ‾atom=μ‾L\underline{\mu}_{atom} = \underline{\mu}_Lμ​atom​=μ​L​ so

ΔEZ=gLμBL‾⋅B‾ΔEZ=gLμBBextML\Delta E_Z = g_L\mu_B\underline{L}\cdot\underline{B}\\ \Delta E_Z = g_L\mu_BB_{ext}M_L ΔEZ​=gL​μB​L​⋅B​ΔEZ​=gL​μB​Bext​ML​

This results from L‾\underline{L}L​ precessing around B‾\underline{B}B​ and is called Larmor precession it results in breaking the degeneracy of MLM_LML​. This splits the observed spectra up into three because of the selection rules of ΔML=0,±1\Delta M_L = 0, \pm1ΔML​=0,±1 so we get ω→ω,ω±Δω\omega \rightarrow \omega, \omega \pm \Delta\omegaω→ω,ω±Δω where

Δω=ΔEZ/ℏ=μBBext/ℏ\Delta\omega = \Delta E_Z/\hbar = \mu_B B_{ext}/\hbar Δω=ΔEZ​/ℏ=μB​Bext​/ℏ

This three splitting is called normal zeeman effect.

Weak Field with Spin Orbit, Anomalous Zeeman

Recall that for spin orbit we needed to use new wavefunctions with different quantum numbers ∣n,L,S,J,MJ>|n,L,S,J,M_J\big>∣n,L,S,J,MJ​⟩. With spin included our perturbation becomes,

ΔEAZ=<−μ‾J⋅B‾ext>=gJμB∣B‾ext∣<J^z>\begin{aligned} \Delta E_{AZ} &= \big<-\underline{\mu}_J\cdot\underline{B}_{ext}\big>\\ &= g_J\mu_B|\underline{B}_{ext}|\big<\hat{J}_z\big> \end{aligned} ΔEAZ​​=⟨−μ​J​⋅B​ext​⟩=gJ​μB​∣B​ext​∣⟨J^z​⟩​

With B‾ext\underline{B}_{ext}B​ext​ oriented in the z direction. BUT WHAT IS gJg_JgJ​?

Supposedly this is a question examiners really like.

To find gJg_JgJ​ we can write μJ\mu_JμJ​ in it's other definition μJ=μS+μL\mu_J = \mu_S + \mu_LμJ​=μS​+μL​ this gives us:

ΔH^AZ=gLμBL‾⋅B‾ext+gSμBS‾⋅B‾ext\Delta \hat{H}_{AZ} = g_L\mu_B\underline{L}\cdot\underline{B}_{ext} + g_S\mu_B\underline{S}\cdot\underline{B}_{ext} ΔH^AZ​=gL​μB​L​⋅B​ext​+gS​μB​S​⋅B​ext​

But what do the dot products evaluate to? This isn't so much of a problem as we only want the time average for ΔEAZ\Delta E_{AZ}ΔEAZ​ so we actually need to look at the dot products of their projections onto J which average stay constant while other components average to zero.

This is because the precess around J in spin-orbit.

This gives us...

ΔEAZ=gLμB<∣L‾⋅J‾∣∣J‾∣2J‾⋅B‾ext>+gSμB<∣S‾⋅J‾∣∣J‾∣2J‾⋅B‾ext>\Delta E_{AZ} = g_L\mu_B\bigg<\frac{|\underline{L}\cdot \underline{J}|}{|\underline{J}|^2}\underline{J}\cdot\underline{B}_{ext}\bigg> + g_S\mu_B\bigg<\frac{|\underline{S}\cdot \underline{J}|}{|\underline{J}|^2}\underline{J}\cdot\underline{B}_{ext}\bigg> ΔEAZ​=gL​μB​⟨∣J​∣2∣L​⋅J​∣​J​⋅B​ext​⟩+gS​μB​⟨∣J​∣2∣S​⋅J​∣​J​⋅B​ext​⟩

We know how to do the dot products L‾⋅J‾\underline{L}\cdot \underline{J}L​⋅J​ and S‾⋅J‾\underline{S}\cdot \underline{J}S​⋅J​ also we know gL=1g_L = 1gL​=1 and gS=2g_S = 2gS​=2 so we get:

ΔEAZ=μB<3J‾2−L‾2+S‾22J‾2JzBext> =3J(J+1)−L(L+1)+S(S+1)2J(J+1)μBBextMJ\begin{aligned} \Delta E_{AZ} &= \mu_B\bigg<\frac{3\underline{J}^2 - \underline{L}^2 + \underline{S}^2}{2\underline{J}^2}J_zB_{ext}\bigg>\\ \ \\ &=\frac{3J(J+1) - L(L+1) + S(S+1)}{2J(J+1)}\mu_B B_{ext}M_J \end{aligned} ΔEAZ​ ​=μB​⟨2J​23J​2−L​2+S​2​Jz​Bext​⟩=2J(J+1)3J(J+1)−L(L+1)+S(S+1)​μB​Bext​MJ​​

This is the same as gJμBBextMJg_J\mu_BB_{ext}M_JgJ​μB​Bext​MJ​ which we got before so we have that,

ΔEAZ=gJμBBextMJ gJ=3J(J+1)−L(L+1)+S(S+1)2J(J+1)\Delta E_{AZ} = g_J\mu_BB_{ext}M_J\\ \ \\ g_J = \frac{3J(J+1) - L(L+1) + S(S+1)}{2J(J+1)} ΔEAZ​=gJ​μB​Bext​MJ​ gJ​=2J(J+1)3J(J+1)−L(L+1)+S(S+1)​

This breaks the degeneracy in M_J, lines split differently because of the half contribution of spin and the different size due to the complicated gJg_JgJ​

Strong Fields, Spin and Orbit, Paschen-Back Effect

A strong field means S‾\underline{S}S​ and L‾\underline{L}L​ precess much faster around B‾ext\underline{B}_{ext}B​ext​ and are independent which means J‾\underline{J}J​ isn't such a good quantum number. Now it's good to use ∣n,L,S,ML,MS>|n, L, S, M_L, M_S\big>∣n,L,S,ML​,MS​⟩ This gives us:

ΔEPB=(ML+2MS)μBBext\Delta E_{PB} = (M_L + 2M_S)\mu_BB_{ext} ΔEPB​=(ML​+2MS​)μB​Bext​

Which is much simpler tbh. We then need to apply the spin orbit correction onto this which means finding <S‾⋅L‾><\underline{S}\cdot\underline{L}><S​⋅L​> but S‾\underline{S}S​ and L‾\underline{L}L​ are precessing so fast around z^\bold{\hat{z}}z^ that only the zzz components matter so we get

ξ<S‾⋅L‾>=ξMLMS\xi<\underline{S}\cdot\underline{L}> = \xi M_LM_S ξ<S​⋅L​>=ξML​MS​

We have six states for L = 1, (ML=1,0,−1,MS=−1/2,+1/2M_L=1,0,-1, M_S=-1/2,+1/2ML​=1,0,−1,MS​=−1/2,+1/2) which lead to shifts in spin orbit of (ξ/2,0,−ξ/2,−ξ/2,0,ξ/2\xi/2, 0, -\xi/2, -\xi/2, 0, \xi/2ξ/2,0,−ξ/2,−ξ/2,0,ξ/2), ignoring the relatively small spin orbit effect we get equally spaced energy levels, the selection rules are ΔML=0,±1\Delta M_L = 0, \pm1ΔML​=0,±1 and ΔS=0\Delta S = 0ΔS=0 since the spin plays no part in the transition we should get a triplet similar to the Normal Zeeman effect and we do!

Putting this all together we get this diagram:

Magnetic Effects In Hyperfine Structure

If we add an external field the hyperfine perturbation becomes

H^3′=AJI‾⋅J‾+gJμBJ‾⋅B‾ext−gIμNI‾⋅B‾ext\hat{H}_3^\prime = A_J\underline{I}\cdot\underline{J} + g_J\mu_B\underline{J}\cdot\underline{B}_{ext} - g_I\mu_N\underline{I}\cdot\underline{B}_{ext} H^3′​=AJ​I​⋅J​+gJ​μB​J​⋅B​ext​−gI​μN​I​⋅B​ext​

As μI<<μJ\mu_I << \mu_JμI​<<μJ​ we can neglect the third term. If AJI‾⋅J‾>>gJμBJ‾⋅B‾extA_J\underline{I}\cdot\underline{J}>>g_J\mu_B\underline{J}\cdot\underline{B}_{ext}AJ​I​⋅J​>>gJ​μB​J​⋅B​ext​ we can call B a weak field, and if AJI‾⋅J‾<<gJμBJ‾⋅B‾extA_J\underline{I}\cdot\underline{J}<<g_J\mu_B\underline{J}\cdot\underline{B}_{ext}AJ​I​⋅J​<<gJ​μB​J​⋅B​ext​ it's a strong field.

Weak Field

In the weak field we have hyperfine effects so F is our good quantum number. This means that

ΔEF=−μ‾F⋅B‾ext\Delta E_F = -\underline{\mu}_F\cdot\underline{B}_{ext}\\ ΔEF​=−μ​F​⋅B​ext​

We can do this the same as the anomalous zeeman effect,

μ‾F=gFμBF‾μ‾F=gJμBJ‾⋅F‾∣F‾∣2F‾\underline{\mu}_F = g_F\mu_B\underline{F}\\ \underline{\mu}_F = g_J\mu_B\frac{\underline{J}\cdot\underline{F}}{|\underline{F}|^2}\underline{F} μ​F​=gF​μB​F​μ​F​=gJ​μB​∣F​∣2J​⋅F​​F​

Here we ignore the III component as it is tiny compared to the JJJ component. Using F=I+JF=I+JF=I+J and our vector dot product trick we get,

gF=gJF(F+1)+J(J+1)−I(I+1)2F(F+1)g_F = g_J\frac{F(F+1) + J(J+1) - I(I+1)}{2F(F+1)} gF​=gJ​2F(F+1)F(F+1)+J(J+1)−I(I+1)​

This leads to a hfs term

ΔE=AF2(F(F+1)+J(J+1)−I(I+1))+gFμBF‾⋅B‾ext\Delta E = \frac{A_F}{2}\bigg(F(F+1)+ J(J+1) - I(I+1)\bigg) + g_F\mu_B\underline{F}\cdot\underline{B}_{ext} ΔE=2AF​​(F(F+1)+J(J+1)−I(I+1))+gF​μB​F​⋅B​ext​

Which gives a simple degeneracy in MFM_FMF​

Strong Field, Back-Goudsmit

In a strong field JJJ couples more strongly to BextB_{ext}Bext​ than to III this means the FFF isn't a good quantum number but MJM_JMJ​ is.

MJM_JMJ​ is the component of JJJ in z direction which is chosen as the direction of the field.

As J‾\underline{J}J​ is precessing around B‾ext\underline{B}_{ext}B​ext​ and I‾\underline{I}I​ precesses slower around the constant part of J‾\underline{J}J​ we get

ΔE∝<I‾⋅J‾z>\Delta E \propto \big<\underline{I}\cdot\underline{J}_z\big> ΔE∝⟨I​⋅J​z​⟩

So the strong shifts become:

ΔEBG=AJMIMJ+gJμBMJBext\Delta E_{BG} = A_JM_IM_J + g_J\mu_BM_JB_{ext} ΔEBG​=AJ​MI​MJ​+gJ​μB​MJ​Bext​

The resulting splitting looks like this with MFM_FMF​ remaining a good quantum number.

Radiation and Transitions

The Atomic Energy levels are important but what what we observe are the actual transitions, so it is important to also look at the physics of these.

Selection Rules

These rules tell us whether an atom can transition from one state to another. If we have solutions to the time dependant schrödinger equation which look like this:

ψi=ϕ(r,θ,ϕ)eiEit/ℏ\psi_i = \phi(r, \theta, \phi)e^{iE_it/\hbar} ψi​=ϕ(r,θ,ϕ)eiEi​t/ℏ

This gives us the perturbation matrix elements of

Pij=<ϕi∣−er‾∣ϕj>ei(Ei−Ej)t/ℏP_{ij} = \big<\phi_i|-e\underline{r}|\phi_j\big>e^{i(E_i-E_j)t/\hbar} Pij​=⟨ϕi​∣−er​∣ϕj​⟩ei(Ei​−Ej​)t/ℏ

Where ϕi=ϕj\phi_i=\phi_jϕi​=ϕj​ we have the stationary states but if Pij!=0P_{ij} !=0Pij​!=0 then we have a transition between those states.

Parity

The parity of the operator er‾e\underline{r}er​ is odd, this means changing rrr to −r-r−r changes the sign of the element. This means that two even or two odd parity states in the matrix element would combine with the odd operator to give an odd integrand, which over all space integrates to 000. So for a trnnsition we need two states of opposite parity which gives the selection rule

Δl=±1\Delta l = \pm1 Δl=±1

This makes physical sense as conservation of angular momentum requires one unit of ℏ\hbarℏ for an electron to jump.

Configuration

Could more than one electron jump? The matrix element below represents this,

=<ϕ1(1s)ϕ2(2p)∣r‾1+r‾2∣ϕ1(3p)ϕ2(3d)>=<ϕ1(1s)∣r‾1∣ϕ1(3p)>×<ϕ2(2p)∣ϕ2(3d)>+<ϕ2(2p))∣r‾2∣ϕ2(3d)>×<ϕ1(1s)∣ϕ1(3p)>=0as =<ϕi(nl)∣ϕi(n′l′)>=0\begin{aligned} &\phantom{=}\big<\phi_1(1s)\phi_2(2p)|\underline{r}_1+\underline{r}_2|\phi_1(3p)\phi_2(3d)\big>\\ &=\big<\phi_1(1s)|\underline{r}_1|\phi_1(3p)\big>\times\big<\phi_2(2p)|\phi_2(3d)\big> + \big<\phi_2(2p))|\underline{r}_2|\phi_2(3d)\big>\times\big<\phi_1(1s)|\phi_1(3p)\big>\\ &=0\\ \text{as } &\phantom{=}\big<\phi_i(nl)|\phi_i(n^\prime l^\prime)\big> = 0 \end{aligned} as ​=⟨ϕ1​(1s)ϕ2​(2p)∣r​1​+r​2​∣ϕ1​(3p)ϕ2​(3d)⟩=⟨ϕ1​(1s)∣r​1​∣ϕ1​(3p)⟩×⟨ϕ2​(2p)∣ϕ2​(3d)⟩+⟨ϕ2​(2p))∣r​2​∣ϕ2​(3d)⟩×⟨ϕ1​(1s)∣ϕ1​(3p)⟩=0=⟨ϕi​(nl)∣ϕi​(n′l′)⟩=0​

So configurations can only change by one electron jump at a time.

Angular Momentum Rules

Again if we consider a single unit of ℏ\hbarℏ angular momentum we have

ΔJ=0,±1 but not 0→0ΔL=0,±1 but not 0→0ΔS=0 as operator doesn’t effect spin\Delta J = 0, \pm1 \text{ but not } 0\rightarrow0\\ \Delta L = 0, \pm1 \text{ but not } 0\rightarrow0\\ \Delta S = 0 \text{ as operator doesn't effect spin} ΔJ=0,±1 but not 0→0ΔL=0,±1 but not 0→0ΔS=0 as operator doesn’t effect spin

Finally we have

ΔMJ=0,±1\Delta M_J = 0, \pm1 ΔMJ​=0,±1

Which isn't too obvious but can be seen in a magnetic field.

X-Ray transitions from inner shells

Transitions of outer "valence" electrons are mostly what we've been thinking about, these give spectra of ∼10−7m\sim 10^{-7}m∼10−7m to 1m1m1m (ultra violet to radio waves). We can disturb the tightly bound inner shell with high energy photons in the keVkeVkeV range, this gives us X-Ray wavelengths. Usually the inner levels are occupied so transitions can only occur if an electron is knocked loose by an energetic photon or free electron.

X-Rays are generated by high energy electrons striking a target, there are two contributions to the spectrum:

  • A continuous distribution produced by the deceleration of charged particles (Bremsstrahlung or braking radiation)
  • Discrete lines produced by inner shell transitions which only appear above a threshold energy

We can say a few things about these discrete lines:

  • The wavelengths fit a simple series formula
  • Lines of the same series appear together once a threshold energy is crossed
  • The threshold energy of a series just exceeds the shortest energy of the shortest wavelength in that series
  • Above a certain energy no new series appear

These observations can be explained by a transition in the inner shell. If the energy is sufficient an electron will be moved to a vacant higher level. The binding energy of the atom will be of the order 10eV10eV10eV so if the incident energy is 103eV10^3eV103eV or more the atom will be ionised. The lines observed then are the transitions from higher levels down into the now vacant spot. In the context of X-rays the n=1,2,3n = 1,2,3n=1,2,3 are known as KKK, LLL, and MMM respectively.

This means the K series is the series produced by higher levels falling into the n=1n=1n=1 shell and the L series if produced by falling into the n=2n=2n=2 shell and so on. The energy of each shell can be expressed by the hydrogenic model:

EN=R(Z−σn)2n2E_N = \frac{R(Z-\sigma_n)^2}{n^2} EN​=n2R(Z−σn​)2​

Where σn\sigma_nσn​ is a screening factor. We can use differences to get a series of wavenumbers νˉ=1/λ\bar{\nu} = 1/\lambdaνˉ=1/λ

νˉ=R{(Z−σK)212−(Z−σi)2ni2}\bar{\nu} = R\bigg\{\frac{(Z-\sigma_K)^2}{1^2} - \frac{(Z-\sigma_i)^2}{n_i^2}\bigg\} νˉ=R{12(Z−σK​)2​−ni2​(Z−σi​)2​}

Where ni=2,3,4,...n_i = 2, 3, 4, ...ni​=2,3,4,... which is how we get a series. The longest wavelength is typically called α\alphaα and the next β\betaβ and so on.

Fine Structure

The X-Ray spectrum is split just like the normal one due to spin orbit. The energy splitting due to fine structure can be written as:

ΔEfs=5.8Z4n3l(l+1)\Delta E_{fs} = \frac{5.8Z^4}{n^3l(l+1)} ΔEfs​=n3l(l+1)5.8Z4​

The x-ray lines are then split by their selection rules,

Δl=±1,Δj=0,±1\Delta l = \pm1, \Delta j = 0, \pm1 Δl=±1,Δj=0,±1

So KαK_\alphaKα​ splits into a doublet Kα1K_{\alpha_1}Kα1​​ and Kα2K_{\alpha_2}Kα2​​

X-Ray Absorption

Two things can happen when X-Rays are absorbed, either an electron is moved to a vacant valence shell or (if energy is high enough) they are ejected from the atom in photoionisation. This latter is far easier as the former makes it much harder to conserve energy and momentum. The result is sharp edges called "absorption edge" where ionisation potential is reached for that series and the chance of absorption becomes much higher.

Auger Effect

The creation of a vacancy can have the simple effect of an electron filling empty level but it cal also result in the ejection of another electron as it gains energy from an electron filling the empty level like so:

The kinetic energy provided is equal to the energy produced by the transition minus the ionation potential of the auger electron, in the above case this gives:

KE=(EK−EL)−ELKE = (E_K-E_L) - E_L KE=(EK​−EL​)−EL​

There are now two vacancies in the LLL shell which could be simply filled or produce more auger effects.

Molecules

Time to take a dip into the domain of chemistry, diatomic molecules. A diatomic molecule is a useful first step because the is always rotational symmetry around the axis that joins the two.

Molecular Energy Estimations

It's useful to get an idea about the scale of various contributions to energy with some order of magnitude estimates.

Electronic Energy

If our valence electron is confined to the region of size aaa then we can use the uncertainty principle:

ΔxΔp=ℏ2→p∼ℏa\Delta x\Delta p = \frac{\hbar}{2} \rightarrow p \sim \frac{\hbar}{a} ΔxΔp=2ℏ​→p∼aℏ​

We can then estimate electronic energy EeE_eEe​ as it'll be of the same order as the kinetic energy

Ee∼p22me=ℏ22mea2E_e \sim \frac{p^2}{2m_e} = \frac{\hbar^2}{2m_ea^2} Ee​∼2me​p2​=2me​a2ℏ2​

If we have that a∼a0a\sim a_0a∼a0​ then EeE_eEe​ is around eVeVeV we can also get a timescale with τe=ℏ/Ee\tau_e = \hbar/E_eτe​=ℏ/Ee​.

Vibrational Energy

We can find vibrational energy by assuming the molecule can be treated as a classical harmonic oscillator. This means

Vvib(x)=12μωvib2x2whereμ=reduced mass=m1m2m1+m2V_{vib}(x) = \frac{1}{2}\mu\omega_{vib}^2x^2\\ \text{where}\\ \mu = \text{reduced mass} = \frac{m_1m_2}{m_1 + m_2} Vvib​(x)=21​μωvib2​x2whereμ=reduced mass=m1​+m2​m1​m2​​

At x∼ax\sim ax∼a all the electronic energy should be vibrational energy so we get

12μωvib2x2∼ℏ22mea2→ωvib∼(ℏ2μmea4)  ⟹  Evib∼meμEe\frac{1}{2}\mu\omega_{vib}^2x^2 \sim \frac{\hbar^2}{2m_ea^2} \rightarrow \omega_{vib} \sim \bigg(\frac{\hbar^2}{\mu m_ea^4}\bigg)\\ \implies E_{vib} \sim \sqrt{\frac{m_e}{\mu}}E_e 21​μωvib2​x2∼2me​a2ℏ2​→ωvib​∼(μme​a4ℏ2​)⟹Evib​∼μme​​​Ee​

So vibrational energy is smaller than electronic energy by around an order of 100.

Rotational Energy

We can treat the molecule as a rigid rotator and ignore the rotation about the axis of symmetry (the axis joining the atoms) as this is a very small moment of inertia. The moment of inertia of the perpendicular axis is I=μa2I=\mu a^2I=μa2 since angular momentum (LLL) is around ℏ\hbarℏ we can say that

L∼Iωrot∼ℏ→ωrot∼ℏI∼ℏμa2L \sim I\omega_{rot} \sim \hbar \rightarrow \omega_{rot} \sim \frac{\hbar}{I} \sim \frac{\hbar}{\mu a^2} L∼Iωrot​∼ℏ→ωrot​∼Iℏ​∼μa2ℏ​

This gives a rotational energy of:

Erot=12Iωrot2=meμEeE_{rot} = \frac{1}{2}I\omega_{rot}^2 = \frac{m_e}{\mu}E_e Erot​=21​Iωrot2​=μme​​Ee​

So order 100001000010000 smaller than EeE_eEe​ and 100100100 smaller than EvibE_{vib}Evib​. So

Ee≫Evib≫Erotτe≪τvib≪τrotE_e \gg E_{vib} \gg E_{rot}\\ \tau_e \ll \tau_{vib} \ll \tau_{rot} Ee​≫Evib​≫Erot​τe​≪τvib​≪τrot​

Another Complicated Hamiltonian

Now we can try actually guessing the Hamiltonian,

Hmolecular=Tn⎵KE of nuclei+Te⎵KE of electrons+V(r‾i,R‾)⎵Potential EnergyH_\text{molecular} = \underbrace{T_n}_\text{KE of nuclei} + \underbrace{T_e}_\text{KE of electrons} + \underbrace{V(\underline{r}_i, \underline{R})}_\text{Potential Energy} Hmolecular​=KE of nucleiTn​​​+KE of electronsTe​​​+Potential EnergyV(r​i​,R​)​​

These terms are

Tn=−ℏ22μ∇R2Te=−∑iNℏ22me∇ri2V(r‾i,R‾)=∑j2∑iN(−Zje24πϵ0∣r‾i−R‾j∣)⎵electron-nuclear interaction+∑i<j>Ne24πϵ0∣r‾i−r‾j∣⎵electron-electron repulsion+Z1Z2e24πϵ0∣R‾∣⎵internuclear repulsionT_n = -\frac{\hbar^2}{2\mu}\nabla^2_R\\ T_e = -\sum^N_i\frac{\hbar^2}{2m_e}\nabla^2_{r_i}\\ V(\underline{r}_i,\underline{R}) = \underbrace{\sum_j^2\sum_i^N\bigg(-\frac{Z_je^2}{4\pi\epsilon_0|\underline{r}_i - \underline{R}_j|}\bigg)}_\text{electron-nuclear interaction} + \underbrace{\sum_{i<j>}^N\frac{e^2}{4\pi\epsilon_0|\underline{r}_i - \underline{r}_j|}}_\text{electron-electron repulsion} + \underbrace{\frac{Z_1Z_2e^2}{4\pi\epsilon_0|\underline{R}|}}_\text{internuclear repulsion} Tn​=−2μℏ2​∇R2​Te​=−i∑N​2me​ℏ2​∇ri​2​V(r​i​,R​)=electron-nuclear interactionj∑2​i∑N​(−4πϵ0​∣r​i​−R​j​∣Zj​e2​)​​+electron-electron repulsioni<j>∑N​4πϵ0​∣r​i​−r​j​∣e2​​​+internuclear repulsion4πϵ0​∣R​∣Z1​Z2​e2​​​

Where R‾1,2\underline{R}_{1,2}R​1,2​ are the positions of the nuclei relative to center of mass. The origin is on the center of mass. This means that we can write the wavefunction:

∣ψ>=∣ψn>∣ψe>|\psi\big> = |\psi_n\big>|\psi_e\big> ∣ψ⟩=∣ψn​⟩∣ψe​⟩

We can split the electronic energy with He=Te+V(r‾i,R‾)H_e = T_e + V(\underline{r}_i,\underline{R})He​=Te​+V(r​i​,R​) which gives us our TISE:

[Tn+He]∣ψn>∣ψe>=E∣ψn>∣ψe>[T_n + H_e]|\psi_n\big>|\psi_e\big> = E|\psi_n\big>|\psi_e\big> [Tn​+He​]∣ψn​⟩∣ψe​⟩=E∣ψn​⟩∣ψe​⟩

Multiplying by <ψe∣\big<\psi_e|⟨ψe​∣ we get:

<ψe∣Tn+He∣∣ψn>∣ψe>=E∣ψn>  ⟹  {<ψe∣Tn∣ψe>+Ee(R)}∣ψn>=E∣ψn>\big<\psi_e|T_n + H_e | |\psi_n\big>|\psi_e\big> = E|\psi_n\big>\\ \implies \bigg\{\big<\psi_e|T_n|\psi_e\big> + E_e(R)\bigg\}|\psi_n\big> = E|\psi_n\big> ⟨ψe​∣Tn​+He​∣∣ψn​⟩∣ψe​⟩=E∣ψn​⟩⟹{⟨ψe​∣Tn​∣ψe​⟩+Ee​(R)}∣ψn​⟩=E∣ψn​⟩

The Born-Oppenheimer Approximation

We can make the Born-Oppenheimer Approximation

Born-Oppenheimer Approximation   ⟹  \implies⟹ Electronic wavefunction has weak dependence on the magnitude RRR of internuclear separation so only the angular part of TnT_nTn​ acts on ∣ψe>|\psi_e\big>∣ψe​⟩

This gives the mathematical mess that is:

He∣ψe>=Ee∣ψe> [−ℏ22μR2∂∂R(R2∂∂R)+<ψe∣N‾2∣ψe>2μR2+Ee(R)]∣ψn>=E∣ψn>H_e|\psi_e\big> = E_e|\psi_e\big>\\ \ \\ \bigg[-\frac{\hbar^2}{2\mu R^2}\frac{\partial}{\partial R}\bigg(R^2\frac{\partial}{\partial R}\bigg) + \frac{\big<\psi_e|\underline{N}^2|\psi_e\big>}{2\mu R^2} + E_e(R)\bigg]|\psi_n\big> = E|\psi_n\big> He​∣ψe​⟩=Ee​∣ψe​⟩ [−2μR2ℏ2​∂R∂​(R2∂R∂​)+2μR2⟨ψe​∣N​2∣ψe​⟩​+Ee​(R)]∣ψn​⟩=E∣ψn​⟩

Where N‾\underline{N}N​ is orbital angular momentum operator of the nuclei.

Rotational and Vibrational Energies

The total angular momentum of electrons and nuclei

K‾=N‾+L‾\underline{K} = \underline{N} + \underline{L} K​=N​+L​

In closed systems

K2∣ψ>=K(K+1)ℏ2∣ψ>Kz∣ψ>=MKℏ∣ψ>K^2|\psi\big> = K(K+1)\hbar^2|\psi\big>\\ K_z|\psi\big> = M_K\hbar|\psi\big> K2∣ψ⟩=K(K+1)ℏ2∣ψ⟩Kz​∣ψ⟩=MK​ℏ∣ψ⟩

Because of the axis of symmetry about the axis LzL_zLz​ is constant. N‾⊥R‾\underline{N}\perp\underline{R}N​⊥R​ by definition so we have Kz=Lz=ΛℏK_z = L_z = \Lambda\hbarKz​=Lz​=Λℏ (ML=ΛM_L = \LambdaML​=Λ by convention)

Remember we need to evaluate <ψe∣N‾2∣ψe>\big<\psi_e|\underline{N}^2|\psi_e\big>⟨ψe​∣N​2∣ψe​⟩ but we have that N‾2=K‾2−L‾2−2N‾⋅L‾\underline{N}^2 = \underline{K}^2 - \underline{L}^2 - 2\underline{N}\cdot\underline{L}N​2=K​2−L​2−2N​⋅L​

As L precesses rapidly we can say that only LzL_zLz​ matters in a time average.

<ψe∣N‾⋅L‾∣ψe>=0  and  <ψe∣L‾2∣ψe>=<ψe∣Lz2∣ψe>=Λ2ℏ2\big<\psi_e|\underline{N}\cdot\underline{L}|\psi_e\big> = 0\ \text{ and }\ \big<\psi_e|\underline{L}^2|\psi_e\big> = \big<\psi_e|L_z^2|\psi_e\big> = \Lambda^2\hbar^2 ⟨ψe​∣N​⋅L​∣ψe​⟩=0  and  ⟨ψe​∣L​2∣ψe​⟩=⟨ψe​∣Lz2​∣ψe​⟩=Λ2ℏ2

This and the fact we can split ψn(R‾)\psi_n(\underline{R})ψn​(R​) into ϕvib(R)ψrot(θϕ)\phi_{vib}(R)\psi_{rot}(\theta\phi)ϕvib​(R)ψrot​(θϕ) gives

H^vib=−ℏ22μ∂2∂R2+Veff(R)Veff(R)=Ee(R)+[K(K+1)−Λ2]ℏ22μR2\hat{H}_vib = -\frac{\hbar^2}{2\mu}\frac{\partial^2}{\partial R^2} + V_{eff}(R)\\ V_{eff}(R) = E_e(R) + \frac{[K(K+1) - \Lambda^2]\hbar^2}{2\mu R^2} H^v​ib=−2μℏ2​∂R2∂2​+Veff​(R)Veff​(R)=Ee​(R)+2μR2[K(K+1)−Λ2]ℏ2​

Spectroscopic Notation

Toby writes a bit about spectroscopic notation for molecules but I'm not sure it's needed.

Selection Rules

With no change in electronic states

ΔK=0,±1 except for ΔK=±1 for Λ=ΔΛ=0Δν=±1\Delta K = 0, \pm1 \text{ except for } \Delta K = \pm1 \text{ for } \Lambda = \Delta\Lambda = 0\\ \Delta\nu = \pm1 ΔK=0,±1 except for ΔK=±1 for Λ=ΔΛ=0Δν=±1

Transitions with a change of electronic state

ΔS=0ΔΛ=0,±1Σ±→Σ±g→u\Delta S = 0\\ \Delta \Lambda = 0, \pm1\\ \Sigma^\pm \rightarrow \Sigma^\pm\\ g \rightarrow u ΔS=0ΔΛ=0,±1Σ±→Σ±g→u

Where Σ±\Sigma^\pmΣ± is the symmetry of Σ\SigmaΣ states (Λ\LambdaΛ can be Σ,Π,Δ\Sigma, \Pi, \DeltaΣ,Π,Δ) and ggg and uuu represent symmetric and antisymmetric states in homonuclear (diatomic molecules with two of the same element) case.
